title: Orthodox Fasting: Spiritual Discipline and Growth
subtitle: Understanding the Orthodox Tradition of Fasting
author: Church Teaching Committee
excerpt: Learn about the Orthodox tradition of fasting, its spiritual benefits, and how to observe fasting periods according to church teaching.

sections.title: The Purpose of Fasting
content: Fasting in the Orthodox Tewahdo Church is not merely abstaining from food, but a **spiritual discipline** that helps us grow closer to God. Through fasting, we learn self-control, develop compassion for those in need, and focus our minds on spiritual rather than material concerns.

Our Lord Jesus Christ Himself fasted for forty days in the wilderness, setting an example for all believers. Fasting is a way of participating in His sacrifice and preparing our hearts for deeper spiritual experiences.

sections.title: Major Fasting Periods
content: The Orthodox Church observes several major fasting periods throughout the year:
**Lent (Hudadi/Abiy Tsom):** The 55-day fast before Easter, the most important fasting period.
**Advent Fast (Tsome Genna):** 40 days of preparation before Christmas.
**Fast of the Apostles:** From the Monday after Pentecost until June 29th.
**Fast of the Assumption:** August 1-15, preparing for the Feast of the Assumption of Mary.

sections.title: Fasting Guidelines
content: During fasting periods, Orthodox Christians traditionally abstain from:
- Animal products (meat, dairy, eggs)
- Fish (except on certain feast days)
- Wine and oil (except on weekends and feast days)
The specific rules may vary based on individual circumstances, health conditions, and pastoral guidance. The emphasis is on spiritual growth rather than strict adherence to dietary rules.

sections.title: Spiritual Benefits
content: Fasting brings numerous spiritual benefits when practiced with the right intention:
**Self-discipline:** Learning to control our desires and appetites.
**Prayer and meditation:** More time and mental clarity for spiritual practices.
**Compassion:** Understanding the hunger of those less fortunate.
**Preparation:** Readying our hearts for major feasts and celebrations.

sections.title: Practical Advice
content: For those new to Orthodox fasting, it's important to start gradually and seek guidance from clergy or experienced members of the community.
Remember that fasting is a means to an end, not an end in itself. The goal is spiritual growth, increased prayer, and deeper relationship with God.
Those with health conditions, pregnant women, children, and the elderly may have modified fasting requirements. Always consult with your priest for personal guidance.
